pros: UNMC has a singular unified mission: excellent patient care. It is what drives every department to excellence. UNMC attracts the best of the best and participates in ground-breaking research. No matter what your job is at UNMC, you are part of the mission, whether it is providing direct patient care or supporting those who do.
cons: You likely won’t see huge pay increases, large bonuses, or big promotions like you would in a corporation. If money is your main motivation, you may want to consider looking elsewhere. UNMC is a government not for profit, and working in this sector does come with some financial drawbacks.

pros: The benefit is good. It is a good university to work or study in.

review_title: Human Resources - Worst Place to Work in Omaha
pros: The pandemic hit and was able to work from home temporarily and away from the staff.
cons: Poor management. Senior employees are ridiculously rude, makes fellow staff literally cry, criticizes every move, management allows the senior level employees to micromanage junior level staff (although the senior level is seen as a peer, not a supervisor), it is so bad that you will not be allowed to respond to an email without having a senior level peer review it first and it is a guarantee that you will be criticized for what you wrote and told to redo it. HR management allows this sort of behavior to continue which is WHY they are constantly having an HR position open at UNMC.

pros: Take the time to find your right fit within the organization. Finding the right team and leadership support has helped me develop professionally and personally. Flexibility to continue education while working. Leadership is willing to leverage your strengths to support your growth. The tuition scholarship is 15 credits per fiscal year. Great collaborators and peers across campus.
cons: Negotiate your salary upfront as annual raises are meager. Limited transparency and lack of strategic focus as an organization.

job_title: Medical Education Coordinator in Omaha, NE
pros: There are some genuine people at UNMC, very nice and fun to work with. You unfortunately have to find them. Independent work, no micromanaging, flexible some times and more now with working from home. There are some great doctors and majority of the students are amazing.
cons: The University is unfortunately geared toward a certain type of people. The environment seems to be set at a standard and or certain status. Those above you may not show you respect especially for the work you do. Huge gaps in pay among other co-workers, overworked and paid pennies in certain areas. Not as diverse as it should be, so there is no support. Can feel a little toxic and stressful at times, and you can't really voice your opinion without someone informing the boss.

pros: Lots of job stability and mostly good coworkers. Good benefits.
cons: The institution is very dysfunctional with broken, slow systems that stand in the way of getting work done. Leadership is disconnected and does little to fix problems other than to say that it’s hard. The environment is filled with microaggressions, sometimes abuse, and toxicity. These behaviors are rarely taken seriously and addressed. Leadership commonly show these behaviors without consequence and because of their position are protected from action.

review_title: Decent Salary - Increase in pay after hire is almost non existent

pros:
Decent benefits, other than salary.
Work-life balance is usually pretty good.
cons:
It can be a repressive and sometimes even oppressive environment.
Employee turnover doesn't seem to garner the attention it should.
Your input will regularly be overlooked, no matter the justification.
Advancement is likely to be achieved only through attrition or internal politics.
DO NOT expect your voice to feel heard.

pros: Good pay, 401k and tuition reimbursement. Finished my degree while working here at a significant savings.
cons:
Consistently had a workload over 40 hrs per week. Very difficult to use my vacation time and actually not work. No back up in my position which was scheduling students for their community rotations. 
Faculty may be knowledgeable in their subject matter but many are horrible leaders/managers.
Promotions are not a given for staff, you must seek and apply for the jobs.
Be aware in many cases, they do not recognize a Bachelor of General Studies from their own university system as adequate for many roles (so much for finishing a degree as an adult learner!)
UNMC will invest in buildings and publicity always, not so much in the people (staff) who are the backbone of university.
Hard push on BLM, diversity and woke culture. You must agree with the agenda or remain silent.

review_title: UNMC is a great entity to work for, but beware of certain labs
job_title: Research Technologist I in Omaha, NE
pros:
Excellent benefits - a lot of PTO, sick days and holidays (in one year, you can earn 12 sick days, 12 vacation days all the generally recognized holidays and 4 or 5? floating holidays). Also offers school credits to University of Nebraska schools.
Great educational environment - a lot of opportunities to go to seminars and listen to a variety of professionals speak. Also great being around excellent scientists and learning from them.
cons:
Beware of which labs you get into. While there are supposedly some labs that are pretty relaxed, there is also a high probability of working for someone who is uptight, disagreeable, a bit neurotic, and, in a couple words, a stereotypical scientist. 

As the saying goes, employees don't leave companies, they leave managers. A potential candidate should be prepared to face stubborn and at times difficult management. 

Many at UNMC are extremely passionate about the work they do, but that tends to not bode too well for the people working under them.

The research being done at UNMC is extremely important, and could have huge impacts on the world. But to get good results (and keep good people), it is necessary to also understand the needs of the workers who are sometimes working long (salaried) hours in an environment not at all conducive to success.

cons: Salary for post docs is low.

cons: Management can sometimes be overburdening, and progress slow.

review_title: it is a good place to do research
job_title: Graduate Student Researcher in Omaha, NE
pros: it has fewer distractions here
cons: sometimes it can be boring to live here

pros: Experience, hours, pay scale, opportunity for self development.
cons: Exposure to bodily hazards, constant stress

pros:
-In-depth experience to pursuing a Ph.D.: learning of future opportunities/jobs after graduation (academia & industry) 
-Able to take graduate courses. 
-Health Insurance, access to student counseling services, gym membership, ability to study anywhere on campus. 
-Exposure student extracurricular activities; constantly dealing with domestic & international students/workers.
-Flexibility at all steps: flexible scheduling (depending on lab) & some flexibility on when to start program and end. 
-Facilitated ability to explore other areas of medicine/research/allied health/public health on campus or meet with current students or program representatives
-Access to many seminar speakers & presentations, clinical boards presentations, etc.
-*Increased consideration upon applying to IGPBS program (applications for this internship is similar to IGPBS application).
cons:
-The commitment must be 10-12 month (not necessarily a bad thing but should keep that in mind)
-Cannot choose labs from another department, only Neuroscience & Pharmacology 
-Small cohort (3-5) spread throughout campus (not a bad thing but it means you'll have to be willing to socialize & initiate many interactions with others.)
-Primary Investigator leadership may not be 'great' depending on what lab you choose.
-Must be finishing up last year of undergrad & able to start the following summer.

review_title: Good place to work, if you have the right job
pros:
Management positions are much better than private industry. Secure jobs if not on grant dollars. Good benefits and time-off policies; generous tuition benefit. Much lower stress than private industry.  

Academic leadership is responsive to majority of needs.  Senior leadership has grand plans...we shall see what they amount to in the long run; difficult to assess at its infancy state.
cons:
Positions are very difficult to get; competition is fierce for even the lowest paying jobs.  Internal advancement prospects are dismal. Lower pay than industry average.  Must follow Board of Regents directives.  

Difficult relationship with Nebraska Medicine (clinical enterprise); they don't know how to play well together, as they are separate companies with different philosophies.  Any position which requires regular collaboration with Nebraska Medicine will be a significant uphill battle.

review_title: Health surveys but care little about health of employees
pros: The benefits of insurance are top notch and if you are good at getting surveys you will get paid a lot in a shorter amount of hours than most jobs.
cons: The chairs were broken in almost all of the work area. The screens are blue, red and yellow - bad for your eyes. Yet you call anywhere from 4-8 hours asking people to do health surveys. The supervisors can be very rude. They talk about different interviewers with their door propped widely open for all other employees to hear. Nothing gets done, even supervisors do not know answers to common employee questions. Lately, for the past few month they've had to cut back on surveys being conducted due to lack of funding and when I left they were laying people off.

job_title: Certified Medical Assistant in Bellevue, NE
pros: Credibility and opportunity to learn about different departments. They are held to a very high standard as far as being well known for their care and their advancements in medicine which makes it an honor to work for them. But at the same time they don't compensate their employees for the hard work that is done. There is always more work added to the everyday job but no recognition being given at any time at all. I am a Certified Medical Assistant with an Associates degree of Applied Science and I make the same amount hourly as the next person in my office without any where near those credentials. UNMC thinks that it is great that you are trying to advance your education however they don't compensate you for it which makes it hard for you to want to stay at an establishment when the main reason you continue your education is for more money.
cons: The pay is terrible and there is no communication between departments and higher up management staff with the employees.

pros: Good hours, decent benefits, excellent employee resources.  Many nice extra perks like free ice skating during winter, discounts on museum admissions for employees.  Caffeteria purchases can be deducted from paycheck with the seipe of your id badge.
cons: Horrible parking situation.  Employees must pay to park or risk a fine.  Parking cost $25/month and the closest space i could get was 4 blocks from my work place.  Applied for other positions within UNMC and even after interviews it took months before a decision was reached. I Worked 2 years on ehat was termed a casual position and none of that eas considered as tenure with UNMC.

pros: Great reputation for patient care in the Midwest.  As a staff physician I only take home call.  Residents stay in-house during the nights and weekends.  The pay of the University of Nebraska Medical Center is comparable to other academic settings in the midwest.  I also enjoy working with students and residents.
cons: The University of Nebraska Medical Center is a large facility.  There is often a lot of red tape to get change accomplished.  An example of this is that I work in an in-effecient clinic setting.   It would be next to impossible to terminate ineffective personnel.  I would have to file formal complaints that would be reviewed by the clinic manager and so on.

review_title: Great place to grow and work!
job_title: Research Technologist II in Omaha, NE
pros: It is a pretty laid back place to work.  There are deadlines from time to time that get tense, but it isn't an everyday occurrence.  They provide a lot of vacation and sick time.  Also, their matching retirement  plan is great!
cons: Doesn't pay as much as industry does.  It is difficult to get anything beyond a cost-of-living raise unless you are also getting a promotion.

pros: Excellent training and progression into management opportunities. Great teamwork and coworkers.
cons: Leads taking full staff at this point, acuity level of patients in a trauma center getting ridiculous for RN to patient ration of 5:1 nights, 4:1 days. Staff if short always. Two new CEOs in two years. New CNO is absent with RNs worries. 3 hrs PTO earned per pay period not enough.

pros: This company has been around a long time and has ties to many organizations. You'll no doubt habe the chance to meet many important figures. You'll be able to meet people from diverse backgrounds. UNMC has a benefits package that at least meets industry standards. Youll fet the experince you need to carry over to any career you want.
cons: Many of the people you work with have been working here a long time which gives them a one track mind. Being the lowest on the totem pole there is no, proving, yourself. You just have to respect and listen to them. Title doesn't matter, just time in.

review_title: It's a good place to be a graduate student.
pros: a. Living cost in Omaha  is fairly low. b. Great scientist team. c. Strong leadership.d. Excellent working environment.  e. The medical school is top-rated too. f. Does have to TA work,but you get paid if you are able to do it.
cons: The weather in Omaha is  not very good, in fact it is horrible during winter time. You need a 4-wheel drive to get around .  Less recreational activities

pros: Great benefits. A step in the right direction (a foot in the door) as I pursue my dream career.
cons: Paying for parking. Hard work doesn't get you anywhere, and it puts a huge target on your back. Little to no salary raise for constantly going above and beyond the duties of the position. Extremely poor management in my department that constantly skated around issues. Human Resources is a joke.

pros: The advantage of doing research in a hospital, is to realize the impact of translational research on patient's life. Gives a strong purposeful motivation.
cons: Even though the research atmosphere is great, some of the mentors are difficult to work with. That can lead to development of stress and impact the mental health of an individual.

pros: UNMC, depending on the department you are in, offers a flexible schedule, and standard hours. The perks of the job are good, with insurance, employee and dependent educational credits, and good networking.
cons: Management of a few department falls upon people who have been there the longest rather than people who are qualified. The pay is generally lower as well for certain jobs than what you could get elsewhere.

review_title: Be careful which position you choose.
pros: Can be a good company if you are in the right department.  I ended up in a very good department with fantastic co-workers that were very supportive and worked well as a team.
cons: Company has some VERY poor managers.  First department I worked in, I had an insecure manager.  Held me back.  Did not utilize me to my fullest potential.

review_title: UNMC is a good school but scientific research is a struggling field.
pros: UNMC has fantastic facilities and talented, smart faculty.
cons: The nature of scientific research is that you are expected to put in long hours for little pay. This would not be an issue if there were light at the end of the tunnel, but there are so many science PhDs graduating that jobs are extremely scarce.

review_title: Good place if you want a job with good benefits and not a lot of pressure or long hours.
pros: Family friendly hours.  Relatively new and nice office environment (furniture, space, ammenities)
cons: Incentives are tied to span of control not to efforts that would improve efficiency or improve profitability like most "for profit" companies.  Very political environment as a result.

review_title: Great company to work for int he metro....
pros: This is a great company to work for. The benefits are excellent, and the people are wonderful. It took 4 months to get hired though. I left this job for another in the public sector.
cons: The compensation is not the best. Many people were unhappy with their salaries. If you were willing to work the second shift there was an incentive though.

job_title: Graduate Research Assistant in Omaha, NE
pros: Salaries are pretty standard now (they became more standardized across campus in 2010, although still vary based on department). Student health insurance is decent, with options to also purchase eye and dental at good rates.
cons: There are no advocates for regulating work hours; 60 - 80 hr work weeks were normal across the board amongst my peers. The Chancelor devalued graduate students at the school as well. No standardization for employer - employee relations and employee rights were enforced.

pros: We are a small research unit in the College of Medicine but it is really wonderful. My PI couldn't be nicer or more understanding and the medical students and interns we work with are very astute.
cons: The downside is that my current position is only part-time. I would be happy to work there full time.

review_title: Great benefits, good environment, good boss but below average market pay.
pros: Good stable job with lots of challenging work.  I believe in the mission of higher education and science research.  The people at the institution are fantastic.
cons: Poor public perception and poor longterm outlook.  This combined with budget trouble and some unclear longer term objectives may make talent look elsewhere for employment.  Technically a government agency so politics often get in the way.

review_title: There are good and bad aspects
pros: The benefits on the university side are very helpful.
cons: Some departments still operate under the good old boy system. If you're female, or haven't been there for over 10 years, be prepared to be thrown under the bus or treated horribly.

job_title: Programmer Analyst II in Omaha, NE
pros: Great benefits (Health Ins, Vacation, Sick leave, life insurance, 401K matching and then some, tuition for dependents(spouse and children to attend Univ. Nebr. school - 15 credit hours per year. Hubby works here as well so our son got 30 credit hours paid per year).
cons: Government job, small raises and budget is based on state budget. If state is having budget issues, not much room for growth salary wise.

review_title: The Office was gave me the chance to learn my duties at a good pace.
job_title: Patient Service Coordinator III in Concord, NC
pros: I transferred within Novant/Presbyterian to be closer to my home in Concord.  This office was 2 minutes from my home and after driving 25 minutes to work for more than 4 years at Farrington Family Medical Novant/Presbyterian I was happy..
cons: It was a small office and my worse fear came to light when the office closed after working for 8 months

job_title: Research Assistant Student in Omaha, NE
pros: Friendly people, Knowledge hub, good place for people wanting to learn research techniques and advance career in future. Low cost of living around. Lot of funding availability in the university as this only state school in Nebraska
cons: The weather is a problem. Most of the winter is snowy and summer sometimes are really hot. No other cons with respect to administrative issues

pros: The health care at present is decent, but the 2018 changes and options are not good.
cons:
Managers are Teflon coated - there are no repercussions for their bad behavior. When complaints were made in regards to management behavior that was in violation of employee rights, management protected management and nothing happens. 
Terrible raises and severely below-the-national-average for salary.
Hideously low morale - caused by heavy-handed management and mismanagement.
Managers who should not be in leadership positions - while this takes place everywhere, UNMC is rife with it. Once a bad manager is in place, it takes an Act of Congress to remove the person.
Poor practices - there is an attitude of :"I know this is broken and inefficient, but we're going to proceed as this is what we've always done."
Cultural Values are on par with the 1950's and change is resisted by the University instead of embraced.
Zero career opportunity to move around within the organization unless you're a Nurse or Doctor.
No Work/Life balance - part of the compensation package is paid sick leave, but you get penalized for using it.
Financial instability of the organization and the massive budget deficit restricts raises and job opportunities within the organization and looming job cuts have many ready to jump ship.
Do More With Less/One Campus One University beaten to death and poorly applied - it's laughable to eliminate a role and expect one person to do the roles of two people. Yet there are repeated higher paying roles in management that are wholly unnecessary.
Unnecessary repeated meetings that rehash the obvious and plans of actions.

pros: Great mission and well-respected institution. Many opportunities for challenging and rewarding projects. I am proud of the work I did there.
cons: Often toxic, sometimes abusive, relationships between faculty and staff.

job_title: Patient Care Tech in Omaha, NE
pros:
Everyone willing to teach the new guy.  Love working with the residents who are still passionate about medicine.
Great benefits.
Good bonuses and shift differentials.
cons:
Low base  salary even compared to Long Term Care facilities around here.
Have to pay for parking each month or risk a 100 ticket.

review_title: Current knowledge lacking, poor opportunities for advancement, frustrating politics
pros: Good benefits package (including tuition)
cons: I suspect its dependent on the department you are employed in. My department was staffed by inept management (poor managerial/operational skills) and frustrated employees which led to much turnover during my 3 year tenure.

pros: Cutting-edge research from basic to translational. Several on-campus collaborations. Access to several core facilities. New research buildings with great labs.
cons: Not aware of a career center/resources. Not enough university housing. Med school/students get pampered while grad students do not often get recognition.

review_title: It has been a very good experience so far
job_title: Graduate Research Assistant in Omaha, NE
pros: Good working and studying enviroment
cons: Good mentors leaving very fast.

job_title: Postdoctoral Research Associate in Omaha, NE
pros: Everyone is friendly, good perks, something fun always going on (like a 'green' inititives, fittness challenges, events)
cons: It's the best medicine-related place to work in the state so it's really competitive, sometimes competition between employees instead of collaboration. Also, I feel that I am underpaid.

pros: Pros: Benefits, great pay, awesome environment, interesting people, you know you're helping to make a difference for others, constant progress in medical science
cons: Can't think of anything! Loved my job and wished I didn't have to leave. Because of health issues, I was forced to resign.

pros: Decent starting wage for a security department
cons: Some of the SO's think they're police officers, which they're not.  Morale was low.  Some people did a lot of work while others did basically nothing.

pros:
Flexibility for working parents
Decent compensation, not high but not too low
Tuition reimbursement and employer contributions to retirement investment opportunities
cons:
Lack of support for professional development 
Opportunities for promotion are only available with attainment of education credentials
Uneven use of university wide policies and procedures by individual departments

pros: Flexible schedule; great benefits; relaxed atmosphere
cons: Hard to give an accurate description as there are so many different types of jobs at this employer that one person's duties and perks can vary greatly to the next.

job_title: Research Technologist II in Omaha, NE
pros: Good work environment. Great people to work with in research. Nice facilities and good benefits.
cons: Little room for advancement in research without a doctoral degree. No incentive bonuses and little recognition for excellence except silly award pins.

pros: Benefits are good and a lot of vacation and sick leave.
cons: Poor pay and no ways to move up in company. Stingy with raises even when you've put in extra time and effort.

pros: Nice environment. The boss is very nice. Omaha is a great city to live in, but far from coasts.
cons:
Poor space for elevation. It is just a starting point for anyone who wants to  be a success.
The benefits for employees are poor.

review_title: Its a graet place to work with great benefits and pay
job_title: Patient Care Tech in Omaha, NE
pros: Benefits Compensation Rewarding Flexible Room for Growth
cons: Floating to different areas that you are not too familiar with

pros: benefits are good, pay is above average
cons: departments do not communicate very well, employee orientation was about diversity and inclusion but did not cover how to navigate the system

review_title: A brief review from a graduate assistant's eye
pros: Provides competitive salary. Omaha is very affordable compared to other cities.
cons: Omaha is far from almost everywhere, and nothing fun to do, other than a giant zoo

review_title: Research Technologist I position at UNMC
job_title: Research Technologist I in Omaha, NE
pros:
This review is only my experience in the laboratory that I was hired to work in. 
Great work environment
Benefits are excellent
Flexible schedule
Decent pay
cons: Fear of running out of grant money

pros: Good place to work and good benefits.  Lots of research, expansion, and developments happenning.  It''s one of the bigger employers in Omaha.
cons: I can't think of any at this time.

job_title: Public Relations Associate in Omaha, NE
pros: Terrific place to work.  Along with partner, Nebraska Medicine, UNMC is transforming lives through health education, research and clinical care.
cons: It is cold in the winter.

job_title: Human Resources Team Member in Omaha, NE
pros: A solid consistent place to work. What you see is what you get!
cons: Funds and salary increases are related to state funding which can impact raises regardless of performance.

pros:
Absolutely the best company I've ever worked for. 
Excellent corporate culture 
Great benefit package
cons: I don't have an advanced degree so it may be difficult for me to advance my career significantly without one.

pros: People in research labs and clinics
cons: Bureaucracy, politics, a lot of red tape

job_title: Office Associate I in Omaha, NE
pros: Good benefits, great people, good work/life balance
cons: Salary stuck at the same place for 3 years, you can only advance if you have a Masters Degree

pros: There is an overwhelming commitment to the patients of the MC.
cons: The employees are in "silos" of leadership and not open to change.

pros: Very good place to work, with comitted, caring, professional colleagues. A beautiful library and place of learning with professional staff.
cons: Parking and the long walk from the parking lot

review_title: Best place to work in Omaha, NE is UNMC.
job_title: RN Staff Nurse in Omaha, NE
pros: This was the best job I ever had, at the Cancer center. I highly recommend.
cons: I really don't think that were any cons for me.

pros: The place is very quiet. People are usually friendly. Low living cost.
cons: In the middle of no where. Not good for your career. A bit boring with life.

review_title: This could be a great stepping stone.
pros: Great benifits, supportive of taking time off.
cons: People hord information, and it is very difficult to get information from anyone. Lots of political games.

pros: you gain the experience that you can put it in your resume
cons: you dont get much money at all

job_title: Graduate Research Assistant in Omaha, NE
pros: flexible schedule as I was going to school at the same time, great work environment, very committed to their work
cons: no cons that I can think of

pros:

job_title: Graduate Research Assistant in Omaha, NE
pros: Not required to TA for intro level chem labs. Heavy focus on lab research and class work.
cons: Not enough guidance through the program to ensure students are progressing.

review_title: My experience at UNMC  has been above average.
pros: Every day is different, and that's a good thing.
cons: Management is a bit daft.

review_title: Great place to work for the patient
pros: Excellent benefits and job security.
cons: Long process for any changes; little advancement opportunities.

pros: Low stress flexible hours good benefits
cons: Limited to no career advancement  job security is up to the principal investigator limited to no motivation to achieve

job_title: Registered Nurse/NP Student in Omaha, NE
pros: There is an atmosphere of family and teamwork. The management is wonderful. Lots of growth

pros: Great staff, awesome benefits, rewarding place to work

review_title: Good place to work in Omaha

pros: Large 401a contributions, up to five weeks per year vacation, decent health insurance

pros: Great families and location.  Good programs for Pre-K students.
